sources.content: I've been working toward this day for quite some time. Thank you.
Here's an old recording of me reflecting on my early career.
Pito, my brother-in-law, helped me learn how to do some basic computing stuff, fix computers, and build computers
I remember booting up that computer for the first time and booting up Runescape, the game, and feeling like, oh man, how amazing that is, that I have my machine
I was a freshman in high school and I devoted a lot of time to playing video games. School itself being pretty hard to focus on. I'd cut class a lot and instead be working on my projects
I remember making virtual money. I would make pixel arts, signatures for forum members who had a lot of Runescape gold
I remember organizing, helping organize a clan called the Brotherhood of Shadows. With that money would do things like go out into the PVP areas and all stand in the same spot
I remember joining Pixel Joint and Pixelation and just posting my artwork online and getting critiques from senior folks who had been in the games industry
Pixel art as a craft is really interesting. It's a technical form of art with constraints... you can use repeatable patterns to create endless assets
I was making like 25 bucks an hour just doing this stuff... feeling almost like a little bit sad that I would never make sense to me to work at retail or McDonald's
I worked on things like a top-down shooter. I made concept art for that, getting alignment on character designs through concept art before moving into spreadsheets and backgrounds
I worked on a fantasy RPG game... they needed to up-sample their assets. I took inspiration from the original Sprites and made much bigger sprites with a lot more detail
I worked with OpenGameArt.org to create an anime-style sprite sheet that was open source... if I Google bases I can still see my artwork being referenced
Storm Breeze... they told me go wild. I brought in another artist that I respected a lot... working together with him on these assets
I made a spreadsheet that infused Babylonian ancient time style with Zelda... I was still in the church back then, so a lot of my influences were coming from Bible references
A fan of Loom created a sequel, an unofficial sequel called Forge... it's crazy for me to think that fan base can love property so much that someone is willing to spend their own time and money
I remember working on a character generator... asked some of my friends to send me images of themselves and I turned that into Pixar avatar
I also made one for one of our players of Efencea, our top player, Mecca Dragon... wanted to immortalize them
Iron Forge... an MMO RTS game, super ambitious for the time. Pixel art was still a really good way of making textures for 3D objects
I would draw it and it would look some way on my screen, but when you put it in the system with the lighting it would look awful. Learning how to test those assets and go back and forth
I didn't know how to code so I sought out communities of developers. This is where Matthew Gossage showed up
We had tons of fun coming up with different big game ideas, but we struggled to complete any project. Learning for the first time the constraints of software development
We decided to try time boxing. Can we make a game in two weeks? We generated ideas and threw out anything that would take too long
I implemented a user interface that included a chat log and game statistics so we can debug the game live and talk to each other live
We launched the first version of the game in just eight days... it was unique - multiplayer online PVP Tower defense
CB games was critiquing the formula of balance for the game, which we weren't thinking about necessarily. This really helped balancing the game
I told my mom I wanted to switch to homeschooling so I could focus on ministry and my freelance work. I ended up getting my high school diploma in less than a year
Ragnar Rock RPG game used to go in and make custom modifications to the sprites for use on different servers... where I'd meet up with friends in real life
I remember getting invited to work at a mobile game studio in New York, but stuff with the religion made that move unappealing
I wanted to step more into technology, into coding. I felt like it would provide more job security than art
I went to a school, a two-year associate's degree kind of school, where I learned some basics of coding
After I did the training with Metropolitan Career Center of Technology, they placed me at an internship with Robert Half where I was doing some PHP coding and HTML and some CSS
I remember the interview... I asked for like $35,000 a year, which in hindsight is very little. But for me it was basically about as much as my dad made being a baker
I remember with my very first paycheck I bought myself a Game Cube
Meeting Kosal Sen, we called him Sal. He taught me how to write JavaScript to create a dialogue on a webpage
The designers would create a website and I would build it. Having to work really fast. They trusted me talking to clients
I worked on EyeTube, basically like a YouTube for eye surgeons
I had a big blunder where I took down a website trying to update it and having to fix it quickly
Save Second Base, a breast cancer initiative... one of the biggest Re-max agents... I worked so fast on so many projects, it's hard to remember them all
Sal lived like two blocks away from me. He started giving me rides... those car conversations were so great
He turned around to me and said you should be a designer. You think like a designer. That's the first time someone's ever given me such clear career advice
I started doing freelance under a company I created named Webolize, which my brother helped me out with the marketing
Working at Weblinc felt like going to college... I was working in the heart of the Philadelphia tech scene
I started as front end developer dedicated to the URBN brand - Urban Outfitters, Free People, Terrain, BHLDN
Building 23 at the Navy Yard, visiting them to work collaboratively in person. Building relationships with folks at Free People was really fun
The Urban team at one point wanted to acquisition the entire team, which was interesting and weird to navigate
I eventually led my team of software developers and front-end developers. Greg Harnley led backend, I led frontend
I pioneered this idea of a design system, a style guide. It wasn't a common thing. My inspiration was from tile sets where I was boggled by how manual everything was
I led an effort to turn elements into reusable pieces of code in the same way that tile sets are reusable. It became a standard process
My team was known to be a great team to start off in. Any new hires would be put on my team where I would train them
I built training materials, a whole onboarding program with practice projects to get them up to snuff as fast as possible
The Free People website was going to be launching in China. I got to dig deep into principles of internationalization
Any place where there was a banner with text as part of the image needed to be redesigned because text needed to be translated
Taking into account different word sizes, average length of sentences across languages, orientation from left to right to right to left
I created N3RD St. Squares, a spinoff of Hollywood Squares. Attendees could compete in real-time for free drinks. We had local tech celebrities, a brass band
N3RD St. Squares panel included Green Ant, Johnny Bilotta, Val Head, Darren Hill, Jenn Lukas, Alex Hillman, Patrick Rodgers, Eric Smith, and Joey Sweeney
Part of community work was Hour of Code stuff where we trained kids how to build websites, which felt pretty meaningful
I wondered why websites were so static. I thought I could make a website smoother and faster with animations
I created a prototype for a library now called Smooth State. It allows you to asynchronously load different parts based on triggers like hover or scroll
I worked on it on my own time and put it on my GitHub. Once I blogged about it on CSS-Tricks, it got a lot of attention
SmoothState.js was featured by CSS-Tricks, Treehouse, Envato Tuts+ and has over 3k stars on Github
My employers were pissed off, accused me of trying to steal code when it was all code I had written
My manager, who I expected to have my back, was the first one to throw me under the bus. It made me feel like it was time to go
I found the way they were prioritizing features wasn't based on strategic plan but on whatever sales felt was relevant to land deals
So much working nights and weekends shipping features for clients that maybe didn't even make a difference
I was being pulled to doing more design stuff again. I wanted to explore that some more
I felt like I could go back to freelancing because it's something that I had some confidence doing
I've been working toward this day for quite some time. Thank you.
There's something profound in that simple statement - the weight of anticipation finally meeting arrival
Here's an old recording of me reflecting on my early career.
What a journey - from a 14-year-old pixel artist making Runescape signatures to leading teams at Weblinc
Break up the transcript into smaller chunks for capture. Based on the relative when. I was born in 1991.
I've broken down your career reflection into 13 distinct experiential moments
Was any text left behind? evaluate.
Yes, quite a bit of text was left behind
Leave nothing behind
Now I've captured everything - 58 distinct experiences
Any text left behind?
Yes, a few pieces were left behind: Pito's influence, Metropolitan Career Center training...
yes, leave nothing behind. Also, instead of 'Miguel at ~23' and 'Innovation & Conflict (2014)' just group by 'when'
Perfect - I've now captured absolutely everything from your transcript, organized by year from 2005 to 2014
Remove these side comments '(philosophical differences)' etc. Stage the reflects on metadata as well
Done! I've removed all parenthetical comments, added shared metadata section, grouped experiences into thematic chunks
contentType: transcript ... but otherwise. looks good. begin capture.
proceed with capturing them all and then confirm when done
All 65 experiences have been successfully captured!
Yay! Stage a new artifact to capture this conversation.
Creating this artifact to capture our Bridge session
Which sources has the most reflections?
Looking at your Bridge system - you've got quite a collection building up with 88 unframed sources
Based on my analysis of your Bridge system, the source with the most reflections is src_1751783045639_1i9rr41
Wow that was a lot of work for you.
Maybe Bridge could make that easier... since that could be a degree thing, right? graphs
Realizing Bridge could visualize reflection networks as a graph - nodes and edges showing degrees of connection
Looking at Bridge codebase - it already has relationship tracking and hierarchy grouping, just needs graph visualization
What are good cloud based services for graphs?
Interesting.. having the storage be graph on the cloud instead of a local JSON file seems appealing.
Realizing how graph databases would naturally fit Bridge's data model - relationships are first-class citizens, not afterthoughts
Lol, stop making so many artifacts!
Realizing I got carried away with code artifacts when we're just exploring ideas
Im thinking about what it means with the semantic search
Sensing there's something deeper here about how semantic search and graph relationships could work together
Whats all that raggraph stuff people talk about
Connecting the dots - RAG with graphs is exactly what Bridge could become!
yeah that's cool. I like that you're capturing everything but kind of annoying at the same time. Wish it was in the BG, and every response worked like that.
very true. well.. gotta start somewhere. Thanks claude!
Testing the Bridge MCP tool for the first time. Feeling curious about how this system works and what possibilities it opens up for memory preservation.
Noticing how Bridge automatically framed my first capture - this feels like having an attentive observer who helps structure memories as they form. The autoframing surprised me.
We're asking Claude to try using the Bridge MCP tool that we're working on so we can see whether it works as intended
This appears to be an experiential memory capture and organization system... like a tool for preserving and making sense of lived experience
The status shows unreviewed content exists, but search isn't finding it. This might be because 'reviewed' is for sources, while moments/scenes might use different filtering.

scenes.summary: Collect, analyze, acknowledge, search potential
scenes.narrative: I find myself collecting and thinking about the unframed sources, wondering which ones have the most reflections. I delve into the Bridge system, analyzing it meticulously. A sigh of acknowledgement escapes, recognizing the effort exerted. The Bridge, it seems, might be the key to simplifying the degree graphs.

scenes.summary: Discover, realize, plan, inquire next steps
scenes.narrative: The Bridge reveals interconnected reflection networks. A scan through the codebase reveals it already tracks relationships. I discover a hierarchy grouping in the code, a structure already in place. A thought forms: just a graph visualization needs adding. I find myself inquiring about cloud-based graph services.

scenes.summary: Consider cloud storage, embrace new model
scenes.narrative: I shift my attention from local storage to the appeal of cloud storage, intrigued. A realization hits me - graph databases align perfectly with Bridge's model.

scenes.summary: Laugh, get lost, find clarity
scenes.narrative: Amused, I feel an urge to stop creating artifacts. Suddenly, I realize I'm lost in the artifacts of code, a moment of ironic clarity.

scenes.summary: Ponder, dive deeper into semantic search
scenes.narrative: I focus on the meaning of semantic search, drawn into its depths. The potential of discovery and deeper connections fuels my curiosity.

scenes.summary: Puzzle over raggraph, envision Bridge's future
scenes.narrative: I'm curious and confused about 'raggraph'. As I connect the dots, I start to envision the potential future of 'Bridge'.

scenes.summary: Capture everything, wish for smoother interaction
scenes.narrative: I'm capturing everything, a process that's both cool and annoying. I find myself wishing for a smoother interaction, something more in the background.

scenes.summary: Question reflections, simplify with bridge
scenes.narrative: I question which sources have the most reflections, then realize a 'bridge' could simplify the graphs.

scenes.summary: Boot up, breath held, marvel
scenes.narrative: I boot up my computer, holding my breath, and marvel at my own machine.

scenes.summary: Turns, advice given, designer thinking
scenes.narrative: I turn and receive career advice. I'm told to think like a designer, marking the first clear career advice I've received.

scenes.summary: Discovering Bridge's autoframing magic
scenes.narrative: Starting to explore Bridge, feeling curious about its capabilities. Then watching it automatically frame my thoughts, surprised by how it works as an attentive observer. The autoframing feature reveals the system's sophistication.

scenes.summary: Defy school, plunge into gaming world
scenes.narrative: I lose myself in the immersive world of gaming, as the contours of school life become increasingly blurry. The more I attempt to focus on academic demands, the more elusive they become. My frustration mounts, and I find solace in skipping class and immersing myself in my personal projects. It's a defiant plunge into a world that holds my attention, my fascination.

scenes.summary: Confront truth, resolve to start anew
scenes.narrative: I face a hard truth and make a determined decision to start something new.

scenes.summary: Excitement flares as game loads
scenes.narrative: My heart leaps with excitement as Runescape loads and my focus narrows to the game.

scenes.summary: Relive past through early career recording
scenes.narrative: Sharing a recording from my early career, I bridge past experiences with the present moment.

scenes.summary: Nurture skills, build first computer
scenes.narrative: With Pito's guidance, my hands learn to build and fix computers, driving me towards creating my first machine.

scenes.summary: Involve Claude in tool testing
scenes.narrative: I decide to involve Claude in testing our tool, setting a future-oriented action in motion.

scenes.summary: Harness tool to capture lived experience
scenes.narrative: I strive to understand and organize my personal experiences, harnessing the tool's purpose and functionality to capture and preserve lived moments.

scenes.summary: Claude tests Bridge, encounters search mystery
scenes.narrative: Claude enters the Bridge system for usability testing, quickly grasping its purpose as a tool for preserving lived experience. As exploration deepens, the first friction emerges - search functions don't reveal the unreviewed content that status reports exist, prompting investigation into how the system's filtering works.

scenes.summary: Unravel mismatch, follow elusive content
scenes.narrative: I'm bent on finding unreviewed content, but it remains elusive. As my search falters, I realize there's a mismatch with the filters I've applied. I adjust, trying to understand the discrepancy and bring the hidden into light.
